head.supplied: Melbourne botanic Garden, ¶ 4. Sept. 1872. ¶ Sir ¶ ¶ I have the honor to draw your attention to the fact, that the reduced estimates of the botanic Garden, as seen by me in the printed schedule just ...

div.p: H72/19018, unit 750, VPRS 44/P inward registered and unregistered correspondence, VA 538 Department of Crown Lands and Survey, Public Record Office, Victoria.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end;

div.p: See also M to J. Casey, 4 September 1872. Melbourne botanic Garden,

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end;

div.p:
I have the honor to draw your attention to the fact, that the reduced estimates of the botanic Garden, as seen by me in the printed schedule just submitted to Parliament, are only covering about the half of the expenditure really required to maintain the establishment in efficient working order. I beg further to submit a schedule, setting forth the number and occupation of the various employees, my own original estimates being prepared in accordance with this schedule, a similar one being submitted to the Lands Office on the 16 July of this year. From this schedule it will be seen, that only one man (Th Gulliver) is constantly and regularly employed in the Gov. House Reserve (with a few of the Orphan boys) and as there the only additional expense was calculated for some water, manure and a few tools, I did not estimate the expenditure for my department in the Gov. House Reserve at more than about £200.- .- during the current financial year, whereas now it is proposed to withdraw the large sum of £1315. 10/- from the Gardenvote for the Gov House Reserve. At the basis of my own estimates, approved of in first instance by the Lands Department, expenditures for more than two months are incurred already, and I therefore regard it my duty to bring these facts at the earliest opportunity before you, and have also the honor to request, that the sum of £1150 may be provided for wages additionally on the estimates and £150 additionally for the storevote of my Department. I beg also to state, that the steam-engine, on which the whole ground has to depend for water supply, is situated within Gov. House Reserve.
MS file annotation initialled by Casey, 11 September 1872: 'Inform the Government Botanist that the Government have approved of the Assistant Commissioner of Crown Lands and Survey's recommendations, and they will be carried into effect without delay. A copy is herewith forwarded and the Govt Botanist is requested to conform thereto — The reasons are there given for the division of the Estimates which have been approved by the Govt and adopted by the Assembly — As the actual extent of the ground which is to be under Govt Botanist's control for the purposes solely of a scientific and practical botanical garden contains (exclusive of lagoon and curved road) only 62 acres, and as he will not henceforth be expected to raise any more plants for extensive distribution as heretofore or to supply any cut flowers, the amount of £1200 for gardeners, laboratory operator, and labourers is deemed sufficient especially when it is considered that he will have the daily services of a very large number of boys from the Industrial School for weeding, clearing paths and other light work which would have to be done by men receiving high wages, if the labour of the boys were not available for such work — The cost of working the engine for raising water can be made a charge in equal proportion on the two separate divisions for Botanic Garden and Government House Domain — Govt. Botanist will immediately submit a schedule containing the name of the laboratory operator, the names of the gardeners and labourers he desires to retain, and the names of those he proposes to transfer to the division of the Government House Domain it being understood that the wages of those he wishes to retain together with half the wages of the engine driver must be kept within the limit of £100 per month —'.
See also M to J. Casey, 16 September 1872.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: I have the honor to be, Sir, your obedient servant

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: The honorable the Minister of the Lands Department

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: center;

div.p:
Employees of the
List written by G. Luehmann. Not all of the staff named have been identified. Those for whom details have been found have entries in the Biographical Register.
